title: Negative sentiment towards equities should unwind, Barclays says

Tue, Sep 22, 2015, 20:26 BST - UK Markets closed Negative sentiment towards equities should unwind, Barclays says By Alexander Bueso | Sharecast â€“ 31 minutes ago 246.65 -8.25 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - Extremely negative sentiment towards equities should unwind, history suggested, a leading research team claimed. Over time, global equities would be able to recover the bulk of recent their losses, Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) said in a research note sent to clients albeit with one caveat. 
The above affirmation rested on their forecasts for corporate earnings panning out. 
"The key to the outlook for global equities is earnings, with global valuations in line with historical averages, a supportive monetary policy backdrop, and very bearish sentiment, a major hit to EPS is the main risk for the market," Barclays went on to say. 
In turn, company profits hinged on two factors, the rate of growth in the world's gross domestic product and oil prices. 
Global GDP would remain above the critical 2.6% threshold through 2016, the broker said, leading to an 8.4% expansion in earnings per share. 
However, while analysts had cut their forecasts for oil producers' earnings by $148bn their forecasts for consumers had only been bumped up by $9bn. 
"This asymmetry leaves scope for an oil 'dividend' whatever happens to oil prices," they concluded. 
The broker said it remained underweight US equities while their largest overweight position was still in Europe ex-UK. 
They also remained overweight on both Japanese and emerging market stocks (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
